review_title: Growing Company, Poorly Integrated, Dysfunctional, Slow at Execution
pros:
- Fantastic 401K match and the vesting period is short compared with competitors
- Great resources (ability to get lab supplies at or near cost)
- Company hosts many exciting events and workshops throughout the year and are great opportunities to gain skills or volunteer
- Company is very lean, and is heavily focused on data metrics and KPIs, I really appreciated the focus on continuous improvement
- The education scholarship is generous, albeit more restrictive compared with other employers
- Healthcare offerings are variable depending on the group and region, some pre-merger legacy plans that Thermo has retained are truly unmatched
- Company has a relatively young, vibrant workforce and is growing
- On-site amenities, including gym and cafeteria (where available) are cheap and accessible
- WFH flexibility is great if you get the right manager and department
cons:
- PTO policy, though on the surface fairly generous at 3 weeks starting, is inflexible and difficult to navigate in my experience compared with competitors (example: maternity leave)
- The company is an agglomeration of a number of smaller companies that were the product of Thermo's buying binge over the past couple of years. There remains quite a bit of overlap and silos that result in unnecessary duplication of functions and resources, territory disputes, office politics, and communication challenges. Except for a very few functions, expect to be frustrated by this on a regular basis.
- Advancement opportunities are lacking and raises are paltry compared with competitors. The company does emphasize "lateral moves" into other roles, which I appreciatively took advantage of during my career at Thermo Fisher. However, in my own experience many times this resulted in others coming in who were completely unfamiliar with a product line that took on a management or oversight role where they have no clear idea what the product really is, how it is used, or how it is manufactured. It is also exhausting to have to re-introduce yourself to your new manager and to justify your existence and importance to the team if you're doing it 3-4 times a year.
- The websites are truly an absolute dumpster fire and the company has no easy solutions to address it. It is difficult to get a customer interested in a product when they themselves cannot find it on the website.
- Constant instability, turnover, layoffs that weren’t fully thought through, and unrealistic expectations. As a result, there was frequently a lot of friction and resulting drama between on-site employees or underhanded tactics from mid-level managers that subsequently amplified the drama and hampered productivity (i.e. artificially inflating numbers, stealing resources and materials from other groups in the middle of the night to "hold down the budget").
- The open-plan office space and dearth of conference and huddle rooms at many larger sites make it logistically difficult to schedule and hold meetings
- Many of the Senior Directors and VP's seem to have an almost "Cult of Personality" problem. While Thermo Fisher has a top-notch Internal Communications and PR Shop, the focus on AV, bright lights, and showmanship versus more open, honest dialogue and communication results in it being an uninformative pablum. Why does there need to be a DJ and produced light show at a site's quarterly Town Hall discussing company performance? Isn't that a bit excessive? Why does the Leadership and Marketing Teams need to frequently come in and disrupt the lab operation to "play act" science for the camera? If you have a question or concern regarding a decision being rolled out from the top, do not expect a speedy or satisfying answer, or even a forum to gain further clarity
- I did experience the ultimate insult of finding out I was about to be laid off but before that was going to happen, I was asked to train my replacement on another continent.
Advice to Management
It is imperative that Thermo Fisher starts adhering to and complying with labor laws regarding safety and rest breaks for hourly workers, something they are (still) continuing to struggle with at some of the California and Oregon sites. The lack of competence, training, and compliance for some managers and supervisors overseeing hourly employees is, at best, inconsistent across groups, and at worst, negligent. This behavior is unacceptable, it is not building trust with the hourly workforce, and is bound to lead to additional legal action (yes, they have a history). Better HR and EHS infrastructure is needed.

Please do a better job of removing barriers to execution that are slowing down innovation and quality! TFS customers are doing incredibly important work and need those products, if there are issues affecting the quality, efficacy, or integrity of products, these must be addressed by management in a rapid, comprehensive, and meaningful way. Slow-walking or being opaque about an issue because a process must be followed or a sales goal needs to be hit are not acceptable and damages the company's reputation.

- San Jose office building and facilities are from the 70s

Provide more avenues for employees to ask questions, provide feedback and move between roles without fear of retribution or bad politics. Don't be afraid to clean house once in a while and weed out the bad actors that suck the innovation and intensity of employees.

pros: Thermo Fisher Scientific is a growing company. The pay is good. The benefits are good. Some of the people who you work with are great.
cons:
The culture and leadership style are like the military. The boss tells you what to do, and you do it, no questions asked. Any comment that is contrary to what anyone else says is taken as a negative comment, even when you are not trying to be negative, but constructive. There is a true fear of having an open and honest conversation, as the discussion will be held against you. You will be labeled as "not a team player" and that is how people may talk about you. Once this happens, your time at Thermo is limited. They have a very high turnover rate. This is due to the fact that 1. they let a lot of people go, and 2. a lot of people want to leave due to the difficult culture. 

This leads to an unbalanced work / personal life. I typically work 12 hour days and some time on weekends. As they "reorganize," which is another name for downsizing, doing the same work with fewer people, the workload gets more difficult. Now their employment is growing, but you need to realize they are acquiring more and more companies. I had a woman work for me for 3 years, and she was happy and worked hard without me asking her to. She moved to a new boss who is more inline with the culture here, and she has been on the phone crying to me in the last 3 months several times. The sad part is no one can say anything to management or HR because then their job is in jeopardy. They are not a "team player." 

Last, one way they manage their cost is they let go of older talent, who also tend to be more expensive. They don't value the experience of the older employees, and thus, they just cut them to save the money. Then, they put someone with much less experience, or no experience in their place, and tell them to just do the job with minimal training.
Advice to Management
It is easy to look at the cost side of everything, but when you look at the value side, you have so much more potential for upside than just cost cutting. I understand that we are running a business, but people make up the business, and people will go the extra mile without the need for fear and intimidation. You set the culture, and the culture needs to change. There is a very hostile work environment for many people, and you can't hear it because they are afraid to speak up. They don't want to lose their jobs because they have bills to pay, kids to put through college, and many people don't like looking for a new job. 

I know it is hard to change, and there is a risk. The company is doing well and growing. So, messing with the culture could put that at risk. But, the human cost is too high. People need to be happy where they work, and not feel intimidated and fearful of their management.
